title: 106_hr5079
content: The "Rural Housing Act of 2000" may be cited as the official title of this Act. It addresses the prepayment of rural multifamily housing loans. Subsection (c) of section 502 of the Housing Act of 1949 is amended to allow prepayment of loans made or insured before December 22, 1979, without restriction. Loans made or insured after December 21, 1979, but before December 15, 1989, may be prepaid without restriction only after 15 years have elapsed from the loan date if no assistance has been received. The Secretary may terminate assistance for housing and related facilities if certain conditions are met, such as no assistance received for 20 years, determination of no longer needing housing, or owner agreeing to extend assistance. The owner must agree to extend low income use restrictions for the remaining period. Loans made or insured after December 14, 1989, under section 514 or 515 of this title cannot be prepaid. Borrowers can request incentives or sell the housing to a nonprofit organization or public agency instead of prepayment. The borrower can receive incentives for extending low-income use restrictions for at least 20 years or sell the housing to a nonprofit organization or public agency instead of prepayment. The borrower can receive incentives such as reduced interest rates, additional rental assistance, equity loans, and incremental rental assistance. Incremental rental assistance may be provided in connection with loans to prevent increases in rental payments for current tenants not receiving rental assistance under specific sections of the United States Housing Act of 1937. Additionally, owners of projects receiving rental assistance under section 8 may receive excess rent for long-term repair or maintenance costs. "If a borrower does not agree to extend low-income use of assisted housing, they may prepay the loan. If the borrower sells the housing to a nonprofit organization or public agency at fair market value, the Secretary can advance certain costs to facilitate the sale." The government can provide advances to nonprofit organizations or public agencies to cover direct costs incurred in purchasing and assuming responsibility for housing and related facilities. They can also approve the assumption of loans and transfer rental assistance payments under certain conditions. The government can provide advances to nonprofit organizations or public agencies for purchasing housing and related facilities. This includes offering loans and transferring rental assistance payments under specific conditions. The government can provide financial assistance to nonprofit organizations or public agencies purchasing housing to ensure low-income families do not exceed maximum rent. Funding from loan prepayments can also be used for incentives and related costs. The government can offer financial aid to nonprofit organizations or public agencies buying housing to prevent low-income families from paying excessive rent. Loan prepayment funds can be used for incentives and costs related to the sale of projects. If a loan is prepaid, the Secretary must provide tenant-based assistance to low-income tenants in the housing. The government can provide financial aid to nonprofit organizations or public agencies purchasing housing to help low-income families avoid high rent. If a loan is prepaid, tenant-based assistance must be provided to low-income tenants in the housing in the form of enhanced vouchers under section 8(t) of the Act. SEC. 3. ENHANCED VOUCHER ELIGIBILITY. Amends Section 8(t)(2) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 to include loans and references section 502(c)(8) of the Housing Act of 1959. SEC. 4. RURAL RENTAL HOUSING LOAN TERM. SEC. 4. RURAL RENTAL HOUSING LOAN TERM. The amendments made by section 735(b)(3) of the Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1998 shall apply to loans made under section 515 of the Housing Act of 1949 if agreed upon by the Secretary of Agriculture and the borrower. Borrowers are not required to accept a new loan for financing the final payment of the original loan.
